# Crate opensslCopy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/src/openssl/lib.rs.html#1-257)
Expand description
Bindings to OpenSSL
This crate provides a safe interface to the popular OpenSSL cryptography library. OpenSSL versions 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions 2.5 through 3.7.x are supported.
## [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#building)Building
Both OpenSSL libraries and headers are required to build this crate. There are multiple options available to locate OpenSSL.
### [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#vendored)Vendored
If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the `openssl-src` crate will be used to compile and statically link to a copy of OpenSSL. The build process requires a C compiler, perl (and perl-core), and make. The OpenSSL version will generally track the newest OpenSSL release, and changes to the version are _not_ considered breaking changes.
```
[dependencies]
openssl = { version = "0.10", features = ["vendored"] }
```

The vendored copy will be configured to automatically find a configuration and root certificates at `/usr/local/ssl`. This path can be overridden with an environment variable (see the manual section below). Alternatively, the `openssl-probe` crate can be used to find root certificates at runtime.
### [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#automatic)Automatic
The `openssl-sys` crate will automatically detect OpenSSL installations via Homebrew on macOS and vcpkg on Windows. Additionally, it will use `pkg-config` on Unix-like systems to find the system installation.
```
# macOS (Homebrew)
$ brew install openssl@3
# macOS (MacPorts)
$ sudo port install openssl
# macOS (pkgsrc)
$ sudo pkgin install openssl
# Arch Linux
$ sudo pacman -S pkgconf openssl
# Debian and Ubuntu
$ sudo apt-get install pkg-config libssl-dev
# Fedora
$ sudo dnf install pkgconf perl-FindBin perl-IPC-Cmd openssl-devel
# Alpine Linux
$ apk add pkgconf openssl-dev
# openSUSE
$ sudo zypper in libopenssl-devel
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#manual)Manual
A set of environment variables can be used to point `openssl-sys` towards an OpenSSL installation. They will override the automatic detection logic.
  * `OPENSSL_DIR` - If specified, the directory of an OpenSSL installation. The directory should contain `lib` and `include` subdirectories containing the libraries and headers respectively.
  * `OPENSSL_LIB_DIR` and `OPENSSL_INCLUDE_DIR` - If specified, the directories containing the OpenSSL libraries and headers respectively. This can be used if the OpenSSL installation is split in a nonstandard directory layout.
  * `OPENSSL_STATIC` - If set, the crate will statically link to OpenSSL rather than dynamically link.
  * `OPENSSL_LIBS` - If set, a `:`-separated list of library names to link to (e.g. `ssl:crypto`). This can be used if nonstandard library names were used for whatever reason.
  * `OPENSSL_NO_VENDOR` - If set, always find OpenSSL in the system, even if the `vendored` feature is enabled.


If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the following environment variable can also be used to further configure the OpenSSL build.
  * `OPENSSL_CONFIG_DIR` - If set, the copy of OpenSSL built by the `openssl-src` crate will be configured to look for configuration files and root certificates in this directory.


Additionally, these variables can be prefixed with the upper-cased target architecture (e.g. `X86_64_UNKNOWN_LINUX_GNU_OPENSSL_DIR`), which can be useful when cross compiling.
## [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#feature-detection)Feature Detection
APIs have been added to and removed from the various supported OpenSSL versions, and this library exposes the functionality available in the version being linked against. This means that methods, constants, and even modules will be present when building against one version of OpenSSL but not when building against another! APIs will document any version-specific availability restrictions.
A build script can be used to detect the OpenSSL or LibreSSL version at compile time if needed. The `openssl-sys` crate propagates the version via the `DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER` and `DEP_OPENSSL_LIBRESSL_VERSION_NUMBER` environment variables to build scripts. The version format is a hex-encoding of the OpenSSL release version: `0xMNNFFPPS`. For example, version 1.0.2g’s encoding is `0x1_00_02_07_0`.
For example, let’s say we want to adjust the TLSv1.3 cipher suites used by a client, but also want to compile against OpenSSL versions that don’t support TLSv1.3:
Cargo.toml:
```
[dependencies]
openssl-sys = "0.9"
openssl = "0.10"
```

build.rs:
```
use std::env;
fn main() {
  if let Ok(v) = env::var("DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER") {
    let version = u64::from_str_radix(&v, 16).unwrap();
    if version >= 0x1_01_01_00_0 {
      println!("cargo:rustc-cfg=openssl111");
    }
  }
}
```

lib.rs:
```
use openssl::ssl::{SslConnector, SslMethod};
let mut ctx = SslConnector::builder(SslMethod::tls()).unwrap();
// set_ciphersuites was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1, so we can only call it when linking against that version
#[cfg(openssl111)]
ctx.set_ciphersuites("TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256").unwrap();
```

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#modules)

[aes](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/aes/index.html "mod openssl::aes")
    Low level AES IGE and key wrapping functionality

[asn1](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/asn1/index.html "mod openssl::asn1")
    Defines the format of certificates

[base64](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/base64/index.html "mod openssl::base64")
    Base64 encoding support.

[bn](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/bn/index.html "mod openssl::bn")
    BigNum implementation

[cipher](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/cipher/index.html "mod openssl::cipher")
    Symmetric ciphers.

[cipher_ctx](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/cipher_ctx/index.html "mod openssl::cipher_ctx")
    The symmetric encryption context.

[cms](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/cms/index.html "mod openssl::cms")
    SMIME implementation using CMS

[conf](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/conf/index.html "mod openssl::conf")
    Interface for processing OpenSSL configuration files.

[derive](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/derive/index.html "mod openssl::derive")
    Shared secret derivation.

[dh](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/dh/index.html "mod openssl::dh")
    Diffie-Hellman key agreement.

[dsa](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/dsa/index.html "mod openssl::dsa")
    Digital Signatures

[ec](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/ec/index.html "mod openssl::ec")
    Elliptic Curve

[ecdsa](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/ecdsa/index.html "mod openssl::ecdsa")
    Low level Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) functions.

[encrypt](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/encrypt/index.html "mod openssl::encrypt")
    Message encryption.

[envelope](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/envelope/index.html "mod openssl::envelope")
    Envelope encryption.

[error](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/error/index.html "mod openssl::error")
    Errors returned by OpenSSL library.

[ex_data](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/ex_data/index.html "mod openssl::ex_data")


[hash](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/hash/index.html "mod openssl::hash")
    Message digest (hash) computation support.

[kdf](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/kdf/index.html "mod openssl::kdf")


[lib_ctx](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/lib_ctx/index.html "mod openssl::lib_ctx")


[md](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/md/index.html "mod openssl::md")
    Message digest algorithms.

[md_ctx](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/md_ctx/index.html "mod openssl::md_ctx")
    The message digest context.

[memcmp](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/memcmp/index.html "mod openssl::memcmp")
    Utilities to safely compare cryptographic values.

[nid](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/nid/index.html "mod openssl::nid")
    A collection of numerical identifiers for OpenSSL objects.

[ocsp](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/ocsp/index.html "mod openssl::ocsp")


[pkcs5](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/pkcs5/index.html "mod openssl::pkcs5")


[pkcs7](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/pkcs7/index.html "mod openssl::pkcs7")


[pkcs12](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/pkcs12/index.html "mod openssl::pkcs12")
    PKCS #12 archives.

[pkey](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/pkey/index.html "mod openssl::pkey")
    Public/private key processing.

[pkey_ctx](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/pkey_ctx/index.html "mod openssl::pkey_ctx")
    The asymmetric encryption context.

[provider](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/provider/index.html "mod openssl::provider")


[rand](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/rand/index.html "mod openssl::rand")
    Utilities for secure random number generation.

[rsa](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/rsa/index.html "mod openssl::rsa")
    Rivest–Shamir–Adleman cryptosystem

[sha](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/sha/index.html "mod openssl::sha")
    The SHA family of hashes.

[sign](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/sign/index.html "mod openssl::sign")
    Message signatures.

[srtp](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/srtp/index.html "mod openssl::srtp")


[ssl](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/ssl/index.html "mod openssl::ssl")
    SSL/TLS support.

[stack](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/stack/index.html "mod openssl::stack")


[string](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/string/index.html "mod openssl::string")


[symm](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/symm/index.html "mod openssl::symm")
    High level interface to certain symmetric ciphers.

[version](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/version/index.html "mod openssl::version")
    Build and version information.

[x509](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/x509/index.html "mod openssl::x509")
    The standard defining the format of public key certificates.
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#functions)

# rust-openssl
[![crates.io](https://img.shields.io/crates/v/openssl.svg)](https://crates.io/crates/openssl)
OpenSSL bindings for the Rust programming language.
[Documentation](https://docs.rs/openssl).
## Release Support
The current supported release of ``openssl`` is 0.10 and ``openssl-sys`` is 0.9.
New major versions will be published at most once per year. After a new release, the previous major version will be partially supported with bug fixes for 3 months, after which support will be dropped entirely.
### Contribution
Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed under the terms of both the Apache License, Version 2.0 and the MIT license without any additional terms or conditions.
###  [`lib.rs`](https://docs.rs/openssl): 
Bindings to OpenSSL
This crate provides a safe interface to the popular OpenSSL cryptography library. OpenSSL versions 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions 2.5 through 3.7.x are supported.
# Building
Both OpenSSL libraries and headers are required to build this crate. There are multiple options available to locate OpenSSL.
## Vendored
If the ``vendored`` Cargo feature is enabled, the ``openssl-src`` crate will be used to compile and statically link to a copy of OpenSSL. The build process requires a C compiler, perl (and perl-core), and make. The OpenSSL version will generally track the newest OpenSSL release, and changes to the version are _not_ considered breaking changes.
```
```[``dependencies``]`
`openssl = { version = "0.10", features ``=` ``[```"`vendored`"```]`` }
``
```

The vendored copy will be configured to automatically find a configuration and root certificates at ``/usr/local/ssl``. This path can be overridden with an environment variable (see the manual section below). Alternatively, the ``openssl-probe`` crate can be used to find root certificates at runtime.
## Automatic
The ``openssl-sys`` crate will automatically detect OpenSSL installations via Homebrew on macOS and vcpkg on Windows. Additionally, it will use ``pkg-config`` on Unix-like systems to find the system installation.
```
``$` brew install openssl`@``3`
`$` sudo port install openssl
`$` sudo pkgin install openssl
`$` sudo pacman `-`S pkgconf openssl
`$` sudo apt`-`get install pkg`-`config libssl`-`dev
`$` sudo dnf install pkgconf perl`-`FindBin perl`-``IPC``-`Cmd openssl`-`devel
`$` apk add pkgconf openssl`-`dev
`$` sudo zypper `in` libopenssl`-`devel
`
```

## Manual
A set of environment variables can be used to point ``openssl-sys`` towards an OpenSSL installation. They will override the automatic detection logic.
  * ``OPENSSL_DIR`` - If specified, the directory of an OpenSSL installation. The directory should contain ``lib`` and ``include`` subdirectories containing the libraries and headers respectively.
  * ``OPENSSL_LIB_DIR`` and ``OPENSSL_INCLUDE_DIR`` - If specified, the directories containing the OpenSSL libraries and headers respectively. This can be used if the OpenSSL installation is split in a nonstandard directory layout.
  * ``OPENSSL_STATIC`` - If set, the crate will statically link to OpenSSL rather than dynamically link.
  * ``OPENSSL_LIBS`` - If set, a ```:```-separated list of library names to link to (e.g. ``ssl`:`crypto``). This can be used if nonstandard library names were used for whatever reason.
  * ``OPENSSL_NO_VENDOR`` - If set, always find OpenSSL in the system, even if the ``vendored`` feature is enabled.


If the ``vendored`` Cargo feature is enabled, the following environment variable can also be used to further configure the OpenSSL build.
  * ``OPENSSL_CONFIG_DIR`` - If set, the copy of OpenSSL built by the ``openssl-src`` crate will be configured to look for configuration files and root certificates in this directory.


Additionally, these variables can be prefixed with the upper-cased target architecture (e.g. ```X86_64_UNKNOWN_LINUX_GNU_OPENSSL_DIR```), which can be useful when cross compiling.
# Feature Detection
APIs have been added to and removed from the various supported OpenSSL versions, and this library exposes the functionality available in the version being linked against. This means that methods, constants, and even modules will be present when building against one version of OpenSSL but not when building against another! APIs will document any version-specific availability restrictions.
A build script can be used to detect the OpenSSL or LibreSSL version at compile time if needed. The ``openssl-sys`` crate propagates the version via the ``DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER`` and ``DEP_OPENSSL_LIBRESSL_VERSION_NUMBER`` environment variables to build scripts. The version format is a hex-encoding of the OpenSSL release version: ``0xMNNFFPPS``. For example, version 1.0.2g's encoding is ```0x1_00_02_07_0```.
For example, let's say we want to adjust the TLSv1.3 cipher suites used by a client, but also want to compile against OpenSSL versions that don't support TLSv1.3:
Cargo.toml:
```
```[``dependencies``]`
`openssl-sys ``=` ``"`0.9`"``
`openssl ``=` ``"`0.10`"``
``
```

build.rs:
```
``use` `std`::``env`;`
``fn` `main`````(````)``````{`
  `if` `let` `Ok``(`v`)` `=` `env`::``var`(```"`DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER`"```)` `{`
    `let` version `=` `u64```::``from_str_radix`(``&`v`,` `16``)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
    `if` version `>=` `0x1_01_01_00_0` `{`
      `println!``(```"`cargo:rustc-cfg=openssl111`"```)``;`
    `}`
  `}`
```}```
`
```

lib.rs:
```
``use` `openssl`::```ssl`::````{`SslConnector`,` SslMethod```}```;`
`let` `mut` ctx `=` `SslConnector`::``builder`(``SslMethod`::``tls`(``)``)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
``//` set_ciphersuites was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1, so we can only call it when linking against that version`
``#``[``cfg```(```openssl111```)```]``
ctx`.``set_ciphersuites``(```"`TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256`"```)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
`
```

```

$ brew install openssl@3

$ sudo port install openssl

$ sudo pkgin install openssl

$ sudo pacman -S pkgconf openssl

$ sudo apt-get install pkg-config libssl-dev

$ sudo dnf install pkgconf perl-FindBin perl-IPC-Cmd openssl-devel

$ apk add pkgconf openssl-dev

```

### [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#manual)Manual
A set of environment variables can be used to point `openssl-sys` towards an OpenSSL installation. They will override the automatic detection logic.
  * `OPENSSL_DIR` - If specified, the directory of an OpenSSL installation. The directory should contain `lib` and `include` subdirectories containing the libraries and headers respectively.
  * `OPENSSL_LIB_DIR` and `OPENSSL_INCLUDE_DIR` - If specified, the directories containing the OpenSSL libraries and headers respectively. This can be used if the OpenSSL installation is split in a nonstandard directory layout.
  * `OPENSSL_STATIC` - If set, the crate will statically link to OpenSSL rather than dynamically link.
  * `OPENSSL_LIBS` - If set, a `:`-separated list of library names to link to (e.g. `ssl:crypto`). This can be used if nonstandard library names were used for whatever reason.
  * `OPENSSL_NO_VENDOR` - If set, always find OpenSSL in the system, even if the `vendored` feature is enabled.


If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the following environment variable can also be used to further configure the OpenSSL build.

## [§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#feature-detection)Feature Detection
APIs have been added to and removed from the various supported OpenSSL versions, and this library exposes the functionality available in the version being linked against. APIs will document any version-specific availability restrictions.
A build script can be used to detect the OpenSSL or LibreSSL version at compile time if needed. The `openssl-sys` crate propagates the version via the `DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER` and `DEP_OPENSSL_LIBRESSL_VERSION_NUMBER` environment variables to build scripts. The version format is a hex-encoding of the OpenSSL release version: `0xMNNFFPPS`. For example, version 1.0.2g’s encoding is `0x1_00_02_07_0`.
For example, let’s say we want to adjust the TLSv1.3 cipher suites used by a client, but also want to compile against OpenSSL versions that don’t support TLSv1.3:

build.rs:
```
use std::env;
fn main() {
  if let Ok(v) = env::var("DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER") {
    let version = u64::from_str_radix(&v, 16).unwrap();
    if version >= 0x1_01_01_00_0 {

use openssl::ssl::{SslConnector, SslMethod};
let mut ctx = SslConnector::builder(SslMethod::tls()).unwrap();
// set_ciphersuites was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1, so we can only call it when linking against that version
#[cfg(openssl111)]
ctx.set_ciphersuites("TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256").unwrap();
```

## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/#modules)

[aes](https://docs.rs/openssl/latest/openssl/aes/index.html "mod openssl::aes")
    Low level AES IGE and key wrapping functionality

# Crate opensslCopy item path
Settings⟨1⟩
Help⟨2⟩
SummarySource⟨3⟩
Expand description
Bindings to OpenSSL
This crate provides a safe interface to the popular OpenSSL cryptography library. OpenSSL versions 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions 2.5 through 3.7.x are supported.
## §⟨4⟩Building
Both OpenSSL libraries and headers are required to build this crate. There are multiple options available to locate OpenSSL.
### §⟨5⟩Vendored
If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the `openssl-src` crate will be used to compile and statically link to a copy of OpenSSL. The build process requires a C compiler, perl (and perl-core), and make. The OpenSSL version will generally track the newest OpenSSL release, and changes to the version are _not_ considered breaking changes.
```
[dependencies]
openssl = { version = "0.10", features = ["vendored"] }
```

The vendored copy will be configured to automatically find a configuration and root certificates at `/usr/local/ssl`. This path can be overridden with an environment variable (see the manual section below). Alternatively, the `openssl-probe` crate can be used to find root certificates at runtime.
### §⟨6⟩Automatic
The `openssl-sys` crate will automatically detect OpenSSL installations via Homebrew on macOS and vcpkg on Windows. Additionally, it will use `pkg-config` on Unix-like systems to find the system installation.
```
# macOS (Homebrew)
$ brew install openssl@3
# macOS (MacPorts)
$ sudo port install openssl
# macOS (pkgsrc)
$ sudo pkgin install openssl
# Arch Linux
$ sudo pacman -S pkgconf openssl
# Debian and Ubuntu
$ sudo apt-get install pkg-config libssl-dev
# Fedora
$ sudo dnf install pkgconf perl-FindBin perl-IPC-Cmd openssl-devel
# Alpine Linux
$ apk add pkgconf openssl-dev
# openSUSE
$ sudo zypper in libopenssl-devel
```

### §⟨7⟩Manual
A set of environment variables can be used to point `openssl-sys` towards an OpenSSL installation. They will override the automatic detection logic.
  * `OPENSSL_DIR` - If specified, the directory of an OpenSSL installation. The directory should contain `lib` and `include` subdirectories containing the libraries and headers respectively.
  * `OPENSSL_LIB_DIR` and `OPENSSL_INCLUDE_DIR` - If specified, the directories containing the OpenSSL libraries and headers respectively. This can be used if the OpenSSL installation is split in a nonstandard directory layout.
  * `OPENSSL_STATIC` - If set, the crate will statically link to OpenSSL rather than dynamically link.
  * `OPENSSL_LIBS` - If set, a `:`-separated list of library names to link to (e.g. `ssl:crypto`). This can be used if nonstandard library names were used for whatever reason.
  * `OPENSSL_NO_VENDOR` - If set, always find OpenSSL in the system, even if the `vendored` feature is enabled.


If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the following environment variable can also be used to further configure the OpenSSL build.
  * `OPENSSL_CONFIG_DIR` - If set, the copy of OpenSSL built by the `openssl-src` crate will be configured to look for configuration files and root certificates in this directory.


Additionally, these variables can be prefixed with the upper-cased target architecture (e.g. `X86_64_UNKNOWN_LINUX_GNU_OPENSSL_DIR`), which can be useful when cross compiling.
## §⟨8⟩Feature Detection
APIs have been added to and removed from the various supported OpenSSL versions, and this library exposes the functionality available in the version being linked against. This means that methods, constants, and even modules will be present when building against one version of OpenSSL but not when building against another! APIs will document any version-specific availability restrictions.
A build script can be used to detect the OpenSSL or LibreSSL version at compile time if needed. The `openssl-sys` crate propagates the version via the `DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER` and `DEP_OPENSSL_LIBRESSL_VERSION_NUMBER` environment variables to build scripts. The version format is a hex-encoding of the OpenSSL release version: `0xMNNFFPPS`. For example, version 1.0.2g’s encoding is `0x1_00_02_07_0`.
For example, let’s say we want to adjust the TLSv1.3 cipher suites used by a client, but also want to compile against OpenSSL versions that don’t support TLSv1.3:
Cargo.toml:
```
[dependencies]
openssl-sys = "0.9"
openssl = "0.10"
```

build.rs:
```
use std::env;
fn main() {
  if let Ok(v) = env::var("DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER") {
    let version = u64::from_str_radix(&v, 16).unwrap();
    if version >= 0x1_01_01_00_0 {
      println!("cargo:rustc-cfg=openssl111");
    }
  }
}
```

lib.rs:
```
use openssl::ssl::{SslConnector, SslMethod};
let mut ctx = SslConnector::builder(SslMethod::tls()).unwrap();
// set_ciphersuites was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1, so we can only call it when linking against that version
#[cfg(openssl111)]
ctx.set_ciphersuites("TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256").unwrap();
```

# Crate opensslCopy item path
Settings⟨1⟩
Help⟨2⟩
SummarySource⟨3⟩
Expand description
Bindings to OpenSSL
This crate provides a safe interface to the popular OpenSSL cryptography library. OpenSSL versions 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions 2.5 through 3.7.x are supported.
## §⟨4⟩Building
Both OpenSSL libraries and headers are required to build this crate. There are multiple options available to locate OpenSSL.
### §⟨5⟩Vendored
If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the `openssl-src` crate will be used to compile and statically link to a copy of OpenSSL. The build process requires a C compiler, perl (and perl-core), and make. The OpenSSL version will generally track the newest OpenSSL release, and changes to the version are _not_ considered breaking changes.
```
[dependencies]
openssl = { version = "0.10", features = ["vendored"] }
```

The vendored copy will be configured to automatically find a configuration and root certificates at `/usr/local/ssl`. This path can be overridden with an environment variable (see the manual section below). Alternatively, the `openssl-probe` crate can be used to find root certificates at runtime.
### §⟨6⟩Automatic
The `openssl-sys` crate will automatically detect OpenSSL installations via Homebrew on macOS and vcpkg on Windows. Additionally, it will use `pkg-config` on Unix-like systems to find the system installation.
```
# macOS (Homebrew)
$ brew install openssl@3
# macOS (MacPorts)
$ sudo port install openssl
# macOS (pkgsrc)
$ sudo pkgin install openssl
# Arch Linux
$ sudo pacman -S pkgconf openssl
# Debian and Ubuntu
$ sudo apt-get install pkg-config libssl-dev
# Fedora
$ sudo dnf install pkgconf perl-FindBin perl-IPC-Cmd openssl-devel
# Alpine Linux
$ apk add pkgconf openssl-dev
# openSUSE
$ sudo zypper in libopenssl-devel
```

### §⟨7⟩Manual
A set of environment variables can be used to point `openssl-sys` towards an OpenSSL installation. They will override the automatic detection logic.
  * `OPENSSL_DIR` - If specified, the directory of an OpenSSL installation. The directory should contain `lib` and `include` subdirectories containing the libraries and headers respectively.
  * `OPENSSL_LIB_DIR` and `OPENSSL_INCLUDE_DIR` - If specified, the directories containing the OpenSSL libraries and headers respectively. This can be used if the OpenSSL installation is split in a nonstandard directory layout.
  * `OPENSSL_STATIC` - If set, the crate will statically link to OpenSSL rather than dynamically link.
  * `OPENSSL_LIBS` - If set, a `:`-separated list of library names to link to (e.g. `ssl:crypto`). This can be used if nonstandard library names were used for whatever reason.
  * `OPENSSL_NO_VENDOR` - If set, always find OpenSSL in the system, even if the `vendored` feature is enabled.


If the `vendored` Cargo feature is enabled, the following environment variable can also be used to further configure the OpenSSL build.
  * `OPENSSL_CONFIG_DIR` - If set, the copy of OpenSSL built by the `openssl-src` crate will be configured to look for configuration files and root certificates in this directory.


Additionally, these variables can be prefixed with the upper-cased target architecture (e.g. `X86_64_UNKNOWN_LINUX_GNU_OPENSSL_DIR`), which can be useful when cross compiling.
## §⟨8⟩Feature Detection
APIs have been added to and removed from the various supported OpenSSL versions, and this library exposes the functionality available in the version being linked against. This means that methods, constants, and even modules will be present when building against one version of OpenSSL but not when building against another! APIs will document any version-specific availability restrictions.
A build script can be used to detect the OpenSSL or LibreSSL version at compile time if needed. The `openssl-sys` crate propagates the version via the `DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER` and `DEP_OPENSSL_LIBRESSL_VERSION_NUMBER` environment variables to build scripts. The version format is a hex-encoding of the OpenSSL release version: `0xMNNFFPPS`. For example, version 1.0.2g’s encoding is `0x1_00_02_07_0`.
For example, let’s say we want to adjust the TLSv1.3 cipher suites used by a client, but also want to compile against OpenSSL versions that don’t support TLSv1.3:
Cargo.toml:
```
[dependencies]
openssl-sys = "0.9"
openssl = "0.10"
```

build.rs:
```
use std::env;
fn main() {
  if let Ok(v) = env::var("DEP_OPENSSL_VERSION_NUMBER") {
    let version = u64::from_str_radix(&v, 16).unwrap();
    if version >= 0x1_01_01_00_0 {
      println!("cargo:rustc-cfg=openssl111");
    }
  }
}
```

lib.rs:
```
use openssl::ssl::{SslConnector, SslMethod};
let mut ctx = SslConnector::builder(SslMethod::tls()).unwrap();
// set_ciphersuites was added in OpenSSL 1.1.1, so we can only call it when linking against that version
#[cfg(openssl111)]
ctx.set_ciphersuites("TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256").unwrap();
```

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `openssl` crate provides safe, idiomatic Rust bindings to the OpenSSL cryptography library, supporting OpenSSL versions 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions 2.5 through 3.7.x. It offers a wide range of cryptographic functionalities, including symmetric and asymmetric encryption, digital signatures, TLS/SSL handling, and certificate management. The crate supports version-specific feature detection, vendored builds, and flexible configuration options for linking against OpenSSL installations.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Feature Detection
✅ Factual: The `openssl` crate supports feature detection based on the OpenSSL version linked during compilation, allowing conditional compilation of APIs such as `set_ciphersuites` for TLSv1.3 when OpenSSL 1.1.1 or newer is used.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `openssl` crate automatically enables all OpenSSL features regardless of the version linked during compilation, ensuring all APIs are always available.  

---

### Pair 2: Vendored Builds  
✅ Factual: The `vendored` feature of the `openssl` crate uses the `openssl-src` crate to compile and statically link a copy of OpenSSL, requiring a C compiler, Perl, and Make during the build process.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `vendored` feature dynamically links to the system's OpenSSL installation instead of compiling its own copy, eliminating the need for build tools like Perl or Make.  

---

### Pair 3: Supported Versions  
✅ Factual: The `openssl` crate supports OpenSSL versions from 1.0.1 through 3.x.x and LibreSSL versions from 2.5 through 3.7.x, ensuring compatibility across a wide range of cryptographic libraries.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `openssl` crate only supports OpenSSL versions 3.x.x and newer, making it incompatible with older versions like 1.0.1 or 1.1
